lessons.title: Moment of a force about a point in 2-D system

items.title: Vector product of two vectors
items.body:
The vector product of two vectors $\vec{A} = (x_1, y_1)$ and $\vec{B} = (x_2, y_2)$ denoted by $\vec{A} \times \vec{B}$ and:
$$ \vec{A} \times \vec{B} = (x_1, y_1) \times (x_2, y_2) = (x_1 y_2 - x_2 y_1) \vec{k} $$

items.title: Moment of a force
items.body:
Moment of a force ($\vec{F}$) about a point (O) and denoted by $\vec{M}_O$:
$$ \vec{M}_O = \vec{r} \times \vec{F} $$

items.title: Algebraic measure of the moment
items.body:
• If $\vec{F}$ tends to rotate the body about O anticlockwise, the algebraic measure is positive (+).
  • If $\vec{F}$ tends to rotate the body about O clockwise, the algebraic measure is negative (-).

items.title: Norm of the moment
items.body:
$$ ||\vec{M}_O|| = F \times L $$
$$ L = \frac{||\vec{M}_O||}{F} $$
Where L is the length of the perpendicular drawn from the center of moment O to the line of action of the force $\vec{F}$.

items.title: Important Note
items.body: The moment of a force about any point on its line of action equals zero.

items.title: General theorem of moments
items.body: The sum of algebraic measures of moments of a set of forces about a point equals the moment of the resultant about the same point.

items.title: Line of action positions
items.body:
• If $\vec{M}_O = \vec{M}_H$, then the line of action of $\vec{R}$ is parallel to $\overline{OH}$.
  • If $\vec{M}_O = -\vec{M}_H$, then the line of action of $\vec{R}$ bisects $\overline{OH}$.
  • If $\vec{M}_O = \vec{0}$, then the line of action of $\vec{R}$ passes through point O.

lessons.title: Moment of a force about a point in 3-D coordinate system

items.title: Moment Vector in 3D
items.body: $$ \vec{M}_O = \vec{r} \times \vec{F} = \begin{vmatrix} \vec{i} & \vec{j} & \vec{k} \\ x & y & z \\ F_x & F_y & F_z \end{vmatrix} $$

items.title: Components of moment
items.body:
• Component of moment about x-axis: $M_x = yF_z - zF_y$
  • Component of moment about y-axis: $M_y = zF_x - xF_z$
  • Component of moment about z-axis: $M_z = xF_y - yF_x$

items.title: Case 1: Same direction
items.body:
If $\vec{F}_1$ and $\vec{F}_2$ are parallel and in the same direction:
  • $R = F_1 + F_2$
  • Direction: Same as $\vec{F}_1$ and $\vec{F}_2$
  • Point of action divides the distance between them internally inversely proportional to ratio of forces: $F_1 \times AC = F_2 \times BC$

items.title: Case 2: Opposite directions
items.body:
If $\vec{F}_1$ and $\vec{F}_2$ are parallel and in opposite directions ($F_1 > F_2$):
  • $R = F_1 - F_2$
  • Direction: Same as the larger force ($\vec{F}_1$)
  • Point of action divides the distance between them externally inversely proportional to ratio of forces: $F_1 \times AC = F_2 \times BC$

lessons.title: Resultant of set of parallel forces

items.title: Magnitude and Direction
items.body: Algebraic sum of forces: $R = \sum F$

items.title: Line of Action
items.body:
Sum of moments of forces about a point = Moment of Resultant about same point.
$$ \sum (F_i \times x_i) = R \times x $$

lessons.title: Equilibrium a set of coplanar parallel forces

items.title: Conditions of Equilibrium
items.body:
A rigid body is in equilibrium under coplanar parallel forces if:
1. Algebraic sum of forces equals zero ($R = 0$).
2. Algebraic sum of moments about any point equals zero ($\sum M = 0$).

items.title: Couple
items.body: A system of two forces of equal magnitudes and in opposite directions and acting in different lines of action.

items.title: Moment of a Couple
items.body: The moment of a couple is a constant vector does not dependent on the point about which we take the moments of the two forces. $$ \vec{M} = \vec{BA} \times \vec{F} = \vec{AB} \times (-\vec{F}) $$

items.title: Norm of the moment
items.body:
Norm of the moment of the couple = magnitude of one of the two forces × the perpendicular distance between the line of action of two forces.
$$ M = F \times L $$

items.title: Sign of algebraic moment
items.body:
• Negative if rotation is clockwise.
  • Positive if rotation is anticlockwise.

items.title: Equilibrium and Equivalence
items.body:
• If two couples are in equilibrium, then the sum of their moments = zero ($M_1 + M_2 = 0$).
  • If two couples are equivalent, then $M_1 = M_2$.

items.title: First case
items.body:
If a set of forces form many couples, then the set is equivalent a resultant couple.
Its moment = the sum of algebraic measure of the moment of these couples.
$$ M = M_1 + M_2 + ... + M_n $$

items.title: Second case
items.body:
A system of coplanar forces is said to be equivalent to a couple if the following two conditions are satisfied together:
1. The sum of the algebraic components of the forces in any direction = zero.
2. The sum of the moment of the forces about any point $\ne 0$.

items.title: Third case
items.body: If the sum of the algebraic measure of the moment of a system of coplanar forces with respect to three non collinear points in its plane is constant and is not equal to zero, this system equivalent to a couple the algebraic measure of its moment equals this constant.

items.title: Fourth case
items.body: If three coplanar forces act on a rigid body and are completely represented by the sides of a triangle taken the same way round, then this system is equivalent to a couple.

items.title: Magnitude of Moment
items.body:
The magnitude of its moment = 2 × the area of the triangle × the magnitude of the force represented the unit length.
$$ ||\vec{M}|| = 2 \times \text{Area} \times \frac{F}{L} $$

items.title: Generalization
items.body: This rule is generalized for more than three forces.
